```{python}
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Sample data for the charts
years = np.arange(2000, 2024)
electricity_demand = np.random.normal(loc=100, scale=15, size=len(years)).cumsum()
demand_growth = np.random.uniform(low=0.5, high=2.0, size=5)  # For 5 regions
energy_mix_2000 = {'Fossil Fuels': 60, 'Nuclear': 20, 'Hydro': 10, 'Renewables': 10}
energy_mix_2020 = {'Fossil Fuels': 45, 'Nuclear': 15, 'Hydro': 10, 'Renewables': 30}
renewable_usage = np.random.normal(loc=50, scale=10, size=len(years)).cumsum()
renewable_price = np.random.normal(loc=100, scale=5, size=len(years)).cumsum()[::-1]  # Decreasing prices
```

# Towards a Brighter Tomorrow: A Data-Driven Journey into an Optimistic Human Future

In a world that often seems overwhelmed by negative headlines, it's easy to overlook the remarkable progress humanity has made. Yet, these advancements come with an increasing demand for energy. Over the past two decades, global energy consumption has soared, with some regions experiencing a doubling in demand. This rise in energy needs poses a significant challenge, calling for innovative solutions and a rethinking of our energy sources.

```{python}
#| label: global-electricity-demand
#| fig-cap: "Global electricity demand over time"

# Create a stacked area chart for electricity demand
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.fill_between(years, electricity_demand, color="skyblue", alpha=0.4)
plt.title("Global Electricity Demand Over Time")
plt.xlabel("Year")
plt.ylabel("Electricity Demand (arbitrary units)")
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()
```
